abstract.para: A firewall zone is a predefined set of rules that dictate how incoming and outgoing network traffic is handled for a specific network interface or source IP address. Each zone represents a different level of trust for the network it's associated with. You can apply different security policies based on where the network connection originates.

topic.para: Zones are like security profiles. For example, you would want to apply different firewall rules for a public Wi-Fi connection and your secure home network. &firewalld; zones allow you to define these distinct sets of rules and apply them accordingly. A network connection is subject to the rules of only one &firewalld; zone. A &firewalld; zone can have many network interfaces or source IP addresses.
The /usr/lib/firewalld/zones/ directory stores the predefined zones. For example:
topic.screen: &prompt.user; /usr/lib/firewalld/zones ls block.xml dmz.xml docker.xml drop.xml external.xml home.xml internal.xml nm-shared.xml public.xml trusted.xml work.xml
topic.para: The default settings of the predefined zones are as follows:

listitem.para: Behavior: All incoming network packets are dropped without any reply. Only outgoing connections initiated from the system are allowed. This provides a "stealth" mode where the system appears non-existent to external attackers.
Use Case: Highly sensitive systems, or temporary isolation.
